comments:
Missing challenger introductions.
Jeopardy! Round clues 10, 11 & 21 archived from transcript of N64 game.

clues.text: Psalm 78 says that among the plagues God sent upon this country was striking its flocks with hot thunderbolts
Exodus's recipe for anointing oil calls for myrrh, cinnamon, sweet salamus, cassia & this oil
He lived 800 years after he begat Seth
9 of the 12 chapters of this man's book set in Babylon revolve around dreams & visions
In the original Hebrew of his "Lamentations", each verse in 3 chapters begins with a new letter, from aleph on
The Hollywood Foreign Press Association
clues.response: the sponsor of the Golden Globes (the one who gives them out)

clues.text: In 1984 Richard Chamberlain, Barbara Stanwyck & Richard Kiley won for their performances in this miniseries
Before her movie stardom, this daughter of Bruce Dern & Diane Ladd was Miss Golden Globe in 1982
In 1989 this "Family Ties" star tied with Judd Hirsch & Richard Mulligan for Best Actor in a Comedy Series
This 1993 Best Actress winner for "Howards End" wished for "the creation of more great female roles"
In a 1932 speech he said, "I pledge you-I pledge myself-to a New Deal for the American people"
His 1988 Democratic Convention speech "wasn't my finest hour. It wasn't even my finest hour and a half"
He's quoted in 1953 as finding himself in the "very small army" of "unemployed presidents"
Kennedy called it "a city of Southern efficiency and Northern charm"
Buchanan hoped this man was "as happy on entering this house as I am in leaving it"
The Catskills are part of the Appalachians running through the southeast part of this state
It's Slide Mountain at 4,204 feet
clues.response: the highest mountain in the Catskills

clues.text: This term for the deep ravines in the Catskills also applies to pieces of garlic
The first Europeans to settle the area were from this country
Thomas Cole & Frederick Church, painters in this school, were known for their Catskill scenes
A biography of this finicky 9-Lives star was published in 1974
The rabbit head logo can be found somewhere on each cover of this men's magazine
Geoffrey, Geegee & Baby Gee are giraffes used by this company
This company's lion was first heard to roar in the 1928 talkie "White Shadows in the South Seas"
The Levi's logo features 2 of these animals trying to pull apart a pair of jeans
It's defined as a traditional song of joy; the "Christmas" type is the most popular
To play the hi-hat type of this percussion instrument, you clash the metal plates together with a pedal
The "Habanera" Bizet included in this opera is an alteration of a tune by the Spanish composer Yradier
As its name implies, this kind of music may be played in a room rather than in a theatre
A visit to Mexico City inspired this "Appalachian Spring" composer to write "El Salon Mexico"
The first edition of his "Common Sense" pamphlet says only that it was "Written by an Englishman"
In 1875 this political "Boss" escaped from jail & fled to Cuba, then to Spain
This inventor of a temperature scale spent most of his life in Amsterdam making weather instruments
Encyclopedia Americana regards him "as the most grotesque figure ever to serve" as Roman emperor
This "Lame" Mongol conqueror died suddenly in 1405 while planning a campaign against China
Though Teflon was discovered in America in 1938, a Frenchman discovered how to coat one of these in 1954
With his invention of the open-jet wind tunnel, he "towers" over other inventors
In 1885 he developed an anti-rabies vaccine
He added an analytic spin to geometry
Joseph Niepce is credited with making the first of these; he produced it on metal in 1826
The 20,000 or so members of this British insurance society are called "names"
It's buying large quantities from manufacturers & selling smaller lots to retailers
This can be the fee paid to an insurance company or the amount a bond sells for above face value
While a put is the right to sell shares at a certain price, this is the right to buy them
This school of economics named for a Briton, stresses the role of government in the economy
It's bordered by every South American country except Chile & Ecuador
15,444-square-mile Marajo Island in the delta of this river was formed by sedimentary deposits
South America's westernmost point is Punta Parinas in this country
The name of this windswept region of Argentina is from a Spanish word for "big feet"
Almost half of the population of this smallest South American country lives in its capital, Paramaribo
In a seafood restaurant, order a bucket of steamers & you'll get these
A dish served a la Jardiniere is served with a variety of these
Connoisseurs of this food often prefer the sevruga over the beluga because it's the finest grained
The German for "crack sausage", it's a short, thick sausage served much the same way as a hot dog
Norwegians call these German Christmas cookies pepperkaker
Frank Norris wrote "The Pit", & he wrote "The Pit and the Pendulum"
A Philip Marlowe novel left unfinished at his death was later completed by Robert B. Parker
To get the right feel for "Show Boat", she lived & worked on one for a couple of months
He not only led the "Beat Generation" movement, he also coined the term
This Pulitzer Prize-winning author of "The Good War" took his first name from a fictional character

rounds.text: The grandfather of this psychiatrist founded the Institute of Hope, a mental hospital in Basel
